A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: My biggest fear after seeing \"The Last Jedi\,\" is that it paves the way for future SW films to get away with cheap\, plot hole mired storytelling\, with a strong indifference\, and almost disdain\, for the legacy established by the title it bears. Not only are tropes established in the original trilogy thrown violently out the window (which I do not mind)\, but subplots established in \"The Force Awakens\,\" TLJ's immediate predecessor\, are also hastily disregarded\, leaving anyone who expected some degree of continuity between the two a little puzzled. Afterall\, are we not viewing a sequel to episode VII\, and one which is part of a larger trilogy? Episode VIII hits the reset button in a way I would expect an initial installment to do so\, and in some ways\, it is so self-contained\, I would prefer to hand out a flashcard to any first time viewer of the new trilogy with the relevant takeaways from episode VII\, so as not to confuse them with back-to-back screenings of the two. If there is one feeling TLJ tries to recapture from the original trilogy\, it is the sense of surprise from major twists\, a la episode V. Sadly\, this film tries to dial the \"twist\" factor up to about 10\, to the point where they simply feel trite. I do not mind risk taking\, nor do I mind the notion of fresh storytelling\, so long as they're carried out in a structured and coherent manner; something which TLJ fails to do.
